0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text:

They began teaching children to jump rope, and people started gathering and holding meetings around the empty space. Currently, there is something to do and a place for exchange. Jump rope has become a means of communication throughout the city, and every evening at 7, there is a jump rope event. Harling, Lena, and Tiny become 'employees' and always come to the jump rope events.

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

2.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on a complicated road near Coventry, hence adding a new guard for the army. Sir John ordered Bardolph to lower his banner and met Peto at the outskirts of the town. He didn't want to lead his troop through the town in its state and with its muddy roads. Therefore, no one among them could pay tolls, as many others had done to return to their normal lives. According to Falstaff, 'Those people were not seen by me.' Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered us on the road and opposed Falstaff's antics. Falstaff remained witty and resourceful when faced with such situations. In fact, Prince Hal was even more pleased with this, rather than being annoyed. Everyone was moving on, Hal said, because Percy had left the playing field.

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

0.text: The next morning Mr. Gardiner starts off for London when no letter from Mr. Bennet arrives. A letter soon arrives from Mr. Collins saying that he has heard of their misfortune, and writing Mr. Bennet that it would be best for him to 'throw off your unworthy child from your affections for ever. Mr. Gardiner writes again saying he has no news yet other than that Wickham does not seem to have any family or friends that they could be staying with, and that he left a number of gambling debts in Brighton. 0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

Mrs. Yeobright rejects his offer. Mrs. Yeobright meets Wildeve and lets him know that he is not her niece's only suitor. Wildeve is still unwilling to commit himself and rushes to meet Eustacia to ask her if she will commit herself to him, but she refuses to do so. Back at home, Captain Vye mentions that Clym Yeobright is returning home from Paris at Christmas.

0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text:
Ambassador Hamilton understands the legal framework for cooperation in the Ley Law. In response to the WTO's trade policy discussion under the Ley Law, he allows for the important programs and governments to negotiate and accept agreements. Hamilton states that the implementation of the agreement is not within the policy jurisdiction of one of the parties. Therefore, he allows for a neutral position for both sides. Others refer to the right to form contracts as limited for the government. Hamilton responds that, unlike Dalasio the Good, the US government can only operate within a specified time frame. He can accept a contract that does not benefit the foreign country but benefits himself, as he will later return to being a regular government. Thus, his power needs to be protected by Congress. However, others argued.

Translation:

Ambassador Hamilton recognizes the legal framework for cooperation in the Ley Law. In response to the WTO's trade policy discussion under the Ley Law, he permits the significant programs and governments to negotiate and approve agreements. Hamilton asserts that the execution of the agreement is not within the jurisdiction of one of the parties. Consequently, he permits a neutral stance for both sides. Others call the right to form contracts limited for the government. Hamilton responds that, unlike Dalasio the Good, the US government can only function within a set timeframe. He can accept a contract that does not benefit the foreign country but benefits himself, as he will later revert to being a regular government. Thus, his power requires protection by Congress. However, others contested.

4.text: Hamilton's ambassador suit understood the legal guidance according to the Law Ley. In the WTO Trade Dispute case under the Law Ley, he exercised a large power and breached a high-level contract. Hamilton's argument for the implementation of the contract was not within the jurisdiction of one of the parties. Therefore, he took on the role between the two parties. The other party called the right to create a contract a limitation of freedom. Hamilton responded that, unlike Dalasio, American freedom can only operate within a defined timeframe. He could enter into a contract that was not beneficial to the foreign country or himself but beneficial to himself, as he would later return to being a normal country. Thus, I am requesting protection from the Congress. However, the other party opposed this.

6.text: Ambassador Hamilton acted in accordance with the Law Ley during the WTO Trade Dispute. He exercised his rights and refused to comply with Dalasio's wishes. Dalasio disagreed with Ambassador Hamilton implementing the agreement. Dalasio considered the right to create the agreement as a limitation of freedom. Hamilton responded by stating, from the American standpoint, freedom can only function within a defined timeframe. He could register a non-beneficial agreement for a foreign country or himself but would eventually return to being a normal country. Therefore, I request protection from Congress. Dalasio opposed this.

8.text: According to WTO Law, Deputy Hamilton exercised his rights and resolved Dalasio's rights in the WTO Trade Week case. Dalasio disagrees with Deputy Hamilton reaching an agreement. Dalasio views the right to create an agreement as a limitation of freedom. Hamilton responded by emphasizing the American perspective, freedom can only operate within a defined time frame. He can register an unprofitable agreement for any country or for himself but will return as a regular country. Therefore, I request protection from the Congress. Dalasio opposes this.

10.text:
According to the WTO Law, Phó Thuộc enforced his own rights and resolved Dalasio's rights in the WTO case of Dalasio. Dalasio did not agree with Phó Thuộc obtaining the contract. Dalasio considered the fact that the contract was obtained as a violation of freedom. Phó Thuộc responded by referring to the US precedent, freedom can only operate within a defined time frame. He can register an indefinite organization contract with any country or with himself but will return to being a regular country. Therefore, I request protection from the Parliament. Dalasio avoided it.

0.text: Linda and Mrs. Bruce go off on vacation, and Linda experiences plenty of ugly prejudice, even though she's working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. The servants won't bring her dinner to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks them to, so she has to go down to the kitchen to get it herself. Finally, Linda puts her foot down and says that Mrs. Bruce is paying for her just like any of the white servants, so she'd better be treated like one of them. This actually works. See, Linda says, you've just got to stand up for your rights.

In her misery, she began again the strange and unpredictable behavior that had marked her in Tostes. Her moods constantly changed, and she was often giddy and nervous. One day Rodolphe Boulanger, a handsome and wealthy landowner, brought one of his servants to be treated by Bovary. 0.text: Jane befriends Diana and Mary, who admire her drawings and give her books to read. St. John, on the other hand, remains distant and cold, although he is never unkind. After a month, Diana and Mary must return to their posts as governesses. St. John has found a position for Jane, running a charity school for girls in the town of Morton. Jane accepts, but St. John presumes that she will soon leave the school out of restlessness, perhaps because he himself is quite restless. His sisters suspect he will soon leave England for a missionary post overseas. St. John tells his sisters that their Uncle John has died and left them nothing, because all his money went to another, unknown, relative. Jane learns that it was Uncle John who led Mr. Rivers into his disastrous business deal

2.text: Jane introduced her friends, Diana and Mary, to Diana and Mary today, who greatly enjoyed all of Jane's paintings and asked to keep her sketches. St. John found Jane a job managing a women's school in Morton. Jane agreed, but St. John excluded her from the school due to the energetic nature of the friends, perhaps because he himself was also very active. They suspected that St. John would soon leave for a foreign country due to legal reasons. They wish to keep Jane in the future and continue communicating with her. Tien Nguyen Tung, also called St. John, approached Jane but then left. A month later, Diana and Mary had to leave the country. St. John helped Jane manage a women's school in Morton. Jane agreed, but St. John was arrested due to issues related to the school, possibly including legal inspections concerning him. It is predicted that St. John will leave the country to resolve this issue.

0.text: Alek and his companions are at the Swiss border in their walker, but a German land frigate is waiting for them. Uh-oh... They decide the only way to get past it is to try to sneak by at night--because everyone thinks piloting a walker at night is too dangerous. The land frigate sends out searchlights at random intervals, which they have to sneak by. They try disguising the walker's noise by walking in a loud streambed. Pretty smart thinking. They run right into some German soldiers on foot, but the walker manages to plow through them. Alek speeds up, taking the walker into a run--at night.

2.text: Alek and his powerful business partner are in the middle of the German-Swiss border with their truck, but a German artillery unit is waiting for them. Oh... They have decided to go through it, a challenge during the night--since trucks cannot be managed at night. The German artillery unit fires short and intermittent, they have to dodge. They try to reduce the noise of the truck by crossing a large river. Yes, they encounter some German ground troops, but the truck can go over them. Alek quickly accelerates, maneuvers the truck at high speed--in the night.

4.text: Alek and his powerful business partner were transporting goods in their relationship with Switzerland, but German customs officials were waiting for them with their trucks. Oh... They had decided to challenge them--because the trucks couldn't go at night. German customs officials fired pyrotechnics and continued the attack. They tried to muffle the sound of the truck's engine by passing through a large river. In vain, they encountered some German ground forces, but the truck was able to get through them. Alek accelerated the truck, returned to the runway--at night.

6.text: Mr. Alek and his partners are transporting their goods through Switzerland, but the German customs manager is waiting for them with their truck. Oh... They have decided to resist--because the truck cannot move at night. The German customs manager held a friendly meeting and continued to pressure them. They challenged the documents by demanding them to pass through a large river. In the distance, they encountered some German military forces, but their truck was able to get past them. Alek quickly accelerated the truck, returned to the runway--in the night.

8.text: Master Alek and his partners were transporting goods through Switzerland, but the German military were waiting for them with their trucks. They had decided to face--for the trucks couldn't move at night. The German military had organized a friendly gathering and continued to pressure them. They put them through a test by requiring them to cross a large river. In the fog, they encountered some German military forces, but their trucks were able to get past them. Alek quickly accelerated the truck, returned to the runway--at night.

They decided to meet--the cargo trucks couldn't move at night. The German military organized a 'coincidental' encounter and continued to pressure them. They demanded that they cross a large river. In thirty minutes, they met the German military a little, but their cargo trucks might have bypassed them. Alek quickly accelerated the truck, returned to the runway--at night.

13.text: Researcher Alek and their Vietnamese partners have good relations with Switzerland, but the German military caused them inconvenience with their trucks. They couldn't move their trucks at night. The German military arranged an unexpected meeting and continued to put pressure on them. They requested to pass through a large river. Thirty minutes later, they encountered the German military again, but their trucks might have bypassed them. Alek quickly made their truck faster, returned to the airport--at night.

0.text: Over two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a wandering life, stopping wherever Jude can find work as a mason. However, he refuses to do any church work. At the little town of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Anny arrive one day. Arabella is now widowed and is in mourning and has come to Kennetbridge to see the laying of a foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims that she has now turned to religion for consolation. She suddenly spots Sue and Little Father Time selling cakes and gingerbread at a stall at the fair. She questions Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter, and they have therefore tried their hand at baking in an attempt to earn a living. Sue now has two children of her own and is expecting a third. The cakes Jude makes are shaped like Christminster colleges, with towers and pinnacles and traceried windows, indicating that Jude still has a passion for Christminster.

2.text: It has been two years. Jude and Sue were leading a nomadic life, stopping at a place so that Jude could find work. However, he had left behind all his training. In the town of Kennetbridge, one day Arabella and Annie arrived. Arabella was very concerned and came to Kennetbridge to investigate the setting up of a new bakery for a new abbey. Jude was suffering from hiver disease, and one day he saw Sue and Doctor Thaddeus selling dumplings and gingerbread on a stage. Arabella asked Sue about Jude and they revealed that he was ill with hiver and they had tried selling the baked goods to keep him alive. Sue had two children and was expecting a third. Jude had the ability to make dumplings in the shape of the universities of Christminster, with their constituent parts and traceried doors, showing that Jude still had the ability to create.

0.text: A French Lord holds a showcase Extravaganza where all the important aristocrats attend. The host snubs the Marquis St. Evremonde and he leaves the reception angrily, ordering his driver to race through the Paris streets. He accidentally runs over a child whose father is Gaspard. He tosses the grief-stricken father a coin and Defarge emerges from the crowd to comfort Gaspard. He throws the coin back into the carriage as it speeds away. The Marquis travels to his country estate where he stops at the village he owns, near his home. A road mender claims he saw a man riding underneath the carriage, who, when it stopped, ran away. The Marquis tells Gabelle, the town official, to be on the lookout for the mystery man. The Marquis travels on to his chateau hoping to meet his nephew M. Charles who is traveling from England.

2.text: The ambassador's ball was a valuable source of happiness, attended by the most creative minds. The ambassador arrived, making a stunning impression, drawing the attention of the Parisian café. He was worried about a young boy named Gaspard and three gold coins. He had sent the coins to his father, then Defarge appeared out of the wind. Defarge took the coins and left in a cart. The cart then drove away. The ambassador went to his country estate near his house. A construction worker saw someone passing under the cart and following it when it stopped. The ambassador had arranged to meet Gabelle, a city official, to welcome the worthy guest. The ambassador continued on his way to meet a gentleman from England, Monsieur Charles, with whom I had a confrontation.

4.text: The embassy is a priceless asset, joined by the most elite investors. The ambassador introduced a unique and alluring generation of café Paris. He was worried about a certain boy named Gaspard and three golden monkeys. He had sent the boy with them, then Defarge appeared out of the wind. Defarge took the two monkeys and left in a carriage. The carriage then left. The ambassador went to his neighboring country. A construction worker saw someone lying under the carriage when it stopped. The ambassador arranged a meeting with Gabelle, a city official, to welcome a distinguished guest. After that, the ambassador went to meet an Englishman, Monsieur Charles, with his business partner.

6.text: The embassy is a prosperous district, joined by large investments. The ambassador introduced a unique and charming student from Café Paris. He turned around a young boy named Gaspard and two little golden statues. He went with them, then Defarge appeared from the wind. Defarge took the little statues and got on a cart. The cart went away. The ambassador went to the international quarters. An employee saw a person sleeping near the cart when it stopped. The ambassador arranged a meeting with Gabelle, the mayor of the city, to welcome a strange guest. Later, the ambassador went to see Monsieur Charles and his partner.

8.text:
The district is expanding rapidly, with significant funding support. Vietnamese Trade Representative introduces a unique and French café lover student named Anh. He returned with two small items and a boy named Gaspard. Den Xuan appeared out of the wind, took those items and got off the car. The car stopped in front of the power plant in the district. A worker saw a person sleeping near the car when it stopped. The Vietnamese Trade Representative called Gabelle, the city mayor, to welcome a foreign guest. Later, the Vietnamese Trade Representative went to see Monsieur Charles and his two education boys of his.

Now that he has an established reputation as a speechmaker, Babbitt is invited to all sorts of functions to give speeches about business and about the glory of Zenith. As his star continues to rise in Zenith's social circles, Babbitt wonders how he ever could have doubted the joys of being a solid citizen.

0.text: The next day, Sue, having changed her mind as usual, writes Jude a note saying he must not come to Shaston. Jude writes back agreeing not to meet her. But on Easter Monday he gets a message from Mrs. Edlin saying that his aunt's health is sinking. Jude rushes to Marygreen to find Aunt Drusilla already dead. He informs Sue, who arrives for the funeral. After the funeral, Sue and Jude have a discussion about Aunt Drusilla's disapproval of marriage for the Fawleys. Sue confesses to an intense physical aversion to Phillotson, although she respects and likes him as a friend. Jude senses her unhappiness and laments the fact that he did not try to prevent her hasty marriage. Sue will not let Jude comfort her and goes off to Widow Edlin's cottage for the night. Later that night, Jude hears the cry of trapped rabbit, and, unable to bear it, he goes out and relieves it of further pain by putting it to death. He finds Sue awake at her window, and she breaks down and pours out all her suffering to him. She finally admits her mistake in not considering the full implications of marriage.

2.text: The following day, Sue, as usual, changed her mind and sent Jude a friendly letter asking for an extension to go to Shaston. Jude agreed to this. We, that is, Jude, received information from Edlin's Ba that Miss Drusilla was ill. Jude rushed to Marygreen only to find that she had passed away. He informed Sue, who went to the family. After calming down, Sue and Jude had a conversation about Drusilla's unusual behavior regarding the Fawleys' marriage. Sue openly declared her feelings to Phillotson, despite his deep love for her. Jude felt intense pain and frustration at not being able to stop Drusilla's disruptive actions. Sue did not allow Jude to openly declare his feelings to him and left to spend a night at Edlin's house. The following night, Jude heard a voice arguing.

After recovering from the shock, Sue and Jude had a conversation about how Miss Drusilla's inappropriate behavior regarding the Fawley matter. 0.text: Once inside the chateau, in his elegant private rooms, the Marquis prepares for supper and awaits his nephew's arrival. When his nephew -- Charles Darnay -- arrives, the two exchange brief formalities and then, after the servants have left, Darnay tells his uncle that he is renouncing all ties to his family and to France. Although he is coolly polite, the Marquis' dislike for his nephew is apparent. Darnay equally despises his uncle, and the fear and hatred inspired by the Evremond name troubles him. Before they part, the Marquis asks about Darnay's relationship with Doctor Manette and Lucie and then smiles mysteriously. In the morning, the Marquis is discovered dead -- stabbed by a member of the Jacquerie.

2.text: In Marquis' house, in his beautiful private room, Marquis was preparing for dinner and waiting for the Vietnamese valet Charles Darnay. When Darnay arrived, they finished their brief conversation, and after the Vietnamese left, Darnay received a letter severing his relationship with the family and France. According to the honorable rules of the Doctors' Order, Marquis also had a strong affection for Darnay, and Darnay, in response, had a strong affection for his father. The sudden and unexpected hostility of Evremond caused tension between them. Before parting, Marquis asked about Darnay's relationship with Dr. Manette and Lucie and then showed them the letters. In the morning, Marquis was found dead - run over by a member of Jacquerie.

4.text: In Marquis' house, in his beautiful personal room, Marquis was preparing for dinner and was waiting for Charles Darnay. When Darnay arrived, they exchanged a brief, friendly greeting, and after Darnay left, he received a sealed letter containing the family name 'Manette' and the word 'France.' According to the reliable and trustworthy word of Dr. Manette, Marquis had a strong affection for Darnay, and Darnay responded with equal affection. Their love was reciprocated from Evrémonde. Before leaving, Marquis asked about Darnay's relationship with Dr. Manette and Lucie and then showed them the letter. That night, Marquis was found dead - killed by a member of the Jacques Rousseau group.

0.text: Countess Gemini has been invited to stay at the Osmonds' for a couple of weeks. The Countess is fond of Isabel, although she and her brother have a mutual dislike for one another. She hopes to find that Osmond has met his match in Isabel. Henrietta visits Countess Gemini, asking whether she knows of Isabel's situation. The outlandish Countess is quite taken with the newspaper woman, and hopes that they can travel to Rome together - she desperately wants her name to appear in the papers. Henrietta's too busy to wait for Countess Gemini's departure, however, and wants see her friend as soon as possible. She plans to leave the next day. Henrietta sends a message to Caspar Goodwood in Florence, and then goes to the Uffizi Museum to look at her favorite painting. Henrietta runs into Caspar at the Uffizi, and they decide to leave for Rome together the next day. Caspar is somewhat hesitant, because he has mixed feelings for Henrietta, but he agrees to travel with her.

0.text: As this scene opens, Cyrano is in a state of frenzied exhilaration because Roxane has acknowledged his existence. He wishes to prove his worth to her by showing his valor. Cyrano offers to offer him protection, by escorting him with a troop of officers. He declares, however, that he will find the attackers alone and unaided. As they prepare to leave, several others join the group, wishing to witness what happens at the Porte de Nesle. When they depart, Cyrano is proudly at the head of the group. He pauses to say that it was necessary to send one hundred men to kill Ligniere because everyone knows he is a friend of his, implying that everyone fears Cyrano.

0.text: The mender of roads who spotted the man under the Marquis St. Evremonde's carriage accompanies Defarge to the wine-shop. In the garret where Doctor Alexandre Manette stayed, Defarge and Jacques One, Two, and Three listen to the road-mender describe what happened to Gaspard, the man who killed the Marquis. Gaspard, who murdered the Marquis for running down his child, went into hiding for nearly a year after the killing. The French authorities recently captured, jailed, and hanged him, and left his corpse dangling by the village fountain, with his shadow poisoning the atmosphere of the town. Monsieur and Madame Defarge later take the road-mender to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles him. Caught up in the emotion of the experience, the road-mender cheers the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges commend his behavior, feeling that it will fuel the courtiers' arrogance and ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, the Defarges believe that the sight of such luxury and finery will supply the road-mender with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

0.text: Ajax and Diomedes run around calling out for Troilus to show his face. So they can smash it in. They bicker about who gets to fight him, until Troilus gets fed up and says that he'll take them both on at the same time.Seriously? Maybe not a good move, dude. They fight their way off the stage as Achilles and Hector show up, going at it with their swords. Hector is getting the better of Achilles and offers to let the guy take a break. This is such a weird battle, you guys. Achilles talks some trash and says something like 'I'll be back' as he runs off. Troilus runs back on stage and says that Ajax has captured Aeneas. 0.text: Joe Welling lives with his mother in Winesburg. Though a man of small stature, he is like a 'living volcano'. He is subject to fits of ideas, whereupon he becomes uncontrollable, words spout from his mouth in torrents, and the person who is his victim then has no escape. He works as an agent for the standard Oil Company, but he can accost anyone on the road and rapidly begin shooting words at him. He is a terror for the Winesburg citizens. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is considered a savior, as he can channel his ideas and excitement into the players and make them win. Joe falls in love with Sarah king a lean, sad-looking woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous, and so is his father Edward, the people of Winesburg can't help laughing at the odd pair but are afraid for Joe. George Willard reports his meeting with the two Kings. Apparently, Joe has managed to sweep away the two, by his torrent of words and ideas. His ideas have managed to perplex the two men and have given them no chance to counter attack Joe.

2.text:

Joe works for Standard Oil, but he can meet anyone on the road and quickly begin analyzing and explaining every word and intention in their minds. Joe is an unhappiness that cannot be found in Winesburg. When Joe organizes a football team, I am considered a savior, because he can transform my thoughtful and active behavior into winning results for the teams. Joe admires Sarah King, a tall, clean, and cheerful woman. My brother Tom is my joy, and my father Edward is the same.

0.text: In the opening chapter, the period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins about fifteen years before the French Revolution. It is a time when many people think they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst of times. The kings of England and France are both mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are put to death for the slightest of crimes. The condition in France is very bad, for there is a total disregard for the common people by the aristocracy; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The aristocracy is unaware that the masses are preparing for the revolution by turning timber into guillotines and farm carts into tumbrels to convey people to the guillotine. In England, too, lawlessness and poverty prevail. Even the colonies in America are up in arms against their English rulers, and the attempts of the American colonies to obtain freedom are not taken seriously.

2.text: Chapter 1, the story takes place during a time described as follows: Twenty-five years before the August Revolution, some considered it a good time, while others considered it a terrible one. The French monarchy and France were considered average intellectuals, clear about their divine rights. In France, formal law was enforced for petty infractions. In France, the common people were ignored and exploited, leading to despotism, cruelty, and corruption. The preparation for social change was not visible to the lords, who turned wooden carts into guillotines and brick carts into tumbrels to transport people to the guillotine. In Beijing, infringements of the law and the struggle for survival continued. The American colonies also possessed their own national rights and were seeking independence, but their intentions were not yet clear.

0.text: The group treads barefoot through a stream in order to hide its tracks. They pass a pond, and Hawkeye tells the group it is filled with corpses of slain French soldiers. As they near the besieged Fort William Henry, they encounter a French sentinel. Heyward talks to him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook sneaks up to the sentinel, kills him, and scalps him. Firing breaks out between English troops protecting the fort and French forces, and the crossfire puts the party in danger. Thick fog conceals them, however, and they attempt to find their way to the fort through the sounds of battle. The French forces pursue them, but they arrive at the fort safely. (Assuming the names 'Doctor Seward' (Bác sĩ Seward), 'Mina Harker' (Mina Harker), 'Van Helsing' (Van Helsing), 'Jonathan' (Jonathan), 'Arthur Holmwood' (Arthur Holmwood), 'Quincey Morris' (Quincey Morris), and 'Renfield' (Reinfeld) are already known in English.)

0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text: At Caesar's banquet, a stormy night. Calpurnia had a premonition about Caesar's wealth. A laborer asked another laborer about a bad omen for a woman to appease it, they came to meet Calpurnia and suggested Caesar leave his house. The laborer returned and told Caesar he should leave. Caesar agreed and sent a message to Antony about his illness. Decius Brutus appeared and explained the omen to Calpurnia. The omen concerned Romans drawing blood from the divine Caesar. Decius interpreted Calpurnia's dream as Caesar's impending suicide causing Roman joy due to his heroism being recognized. Decius suggested Sen cleanse Caesar as he was troubled by his wife's dream. Caesar changed his mind and went to Capitol. Caesar greeted Antony, but Antony was still affected by the party.

4.text: At Caesar's tavern that night, wind and rain were stirring. Calpurnia was uneasy about Caesar's power. A laborer asked another about an ominous sign for a happy man, and they encountered Calpurnia, who suggested that Caesar leave his house. The omen concerned a Roman drawing blood from Caesar, revealing Caesar's own destruction and Rome's joy. Decius suggested that Servius cleanse Caesar to cancel out the omen's effect. Caesar changed his mind and went to Capitol. Caesar greeted Antony, but Antony was still affected by the matter.

The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

0.text: In the year 1640, the Hall of the Hotel de Bourgogne--a large, crowded Parisian theater--buzzes with activity in the minutes before a performance of the play La Clorise. People mill about and converse, divided according to their social class. A citizen guides his son through the room, impressing upon him the intellectual magnitude of the performance. A thief moves through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and purses. A group of pages runs about firing peashooters at one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords strapped to their waists, tread through the crowd, aloof and condescending. The lamps are lit, and the crowd cheers, knowing the performance will commence soon

2.text: In the year 1640, the grand and complete banquet hall of Hotel de Bourgogne in Paris, known as Sach tavern Hall, was bustling with activity before a performance of La Cloris. 0.text: On Christmas morning Jim wakes up to see the men coming in from their morning chores. They all shout 'Merry Christmas' to each other. Grandfather says particularly long prayers that morning and reads aloud from the Bible. He thanks God for Christmas. Narrator-Jim remarks that Grandfather had a special talent for saying prayers. They have waffles and sausage for breakfast. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas were happy with their presents, even Ambrosch. That afternoon Jake and Jim play marbles while Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every Christmas. At 4pm Mr. Shimerda shows up with his rabbit-skin winter gear. He's there to thank them for everything they've done for his family. He seems to be very content, though it's only a break from his constant sadness. At 9pm, he leaves to go home. As he departs, he makes the sign of the cross over Grandmother and tells her that she's a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are good.

Jim was fascinated by their unique way of revering God for Christmas. They spoke very beautifully. They ate waffles and syrup for breakfast. Jake announced that Shimerdas were still happy and a little more eccentric, even than Ambrosch. In the afternoon, they played charades, while Otto wrote a letter to his mother, following the tradition of every Christmas. At 4 o'clock, Mr. Shimerda appeared with a jolly Santa Claus. He came to reward the family. He felt joyful, but it was only a break from the usual Christmas happiness. At 9 o'clock, he left and left a trail of footprints behind.

0.text: Isabel is doing a lot of thinking. We learn about her thoughts on her marriage to Osmond and Lord Warburton's pursuit of Pansy. Isabel wonders if she gave a false image of herself to Osmond when they first got involved. Isabel feels certain that Osmond hates her, because she doesn't have a sense of 'tradition.' Well, of course not - isn't her originality the very thing that people love about her? Not only does he hate her opinions and beliefs, he also takes offense to the whole manner with which she conducts her life. We discover the grim truth behind their relationship: Osmond has gradually gained total control of Isabel, who was once so proud and independent. Isabel and Osmond have barely been speaking to one another. Isabel knows that Osmond is upset and jealous about Ralph's stay in Rome. Isabel has not told Ralph how miserable her life is. She thinks that it is better for him to think that he was wrong all along, although, in fact, he was all too right. Isabel stays up until four in the morning thinking things over. She can't shake off the alarming image of Madame Merle and Osmond in cahoots.

0.text: Jim finally says good-bye and leaves for Black Hawk. Jim is sad to leave Ambrosch, whom he likes so much. He tells him and Rudolph that they'll go hunting together next summer. Jim doesn't enjoy his day in Black Hawk because he doesn't recognize most of the people there. He hangs out with Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer who fills him in on the details of the Cutter case. He walks outside of the town to look at the landscape. He feels at home again. He stumbles on the old road that leads out to his grandfather's old farm. It's mostly been ploughed under. Jim sits down and looks out at the sun. He remembers the night he arrived on the train from Virginia. He feels as though he and Antonia walked on the road of destiny to get where they are today, and that they possess the past together.

2.text:
Jim set off early in the morning and determinedly made his way to Black Hawk. Jim felt sad as he had to leave Ambrosch, a man he deeply loved. Coco had entrusted Anhang and Rudolph, and they promised to go hunting together every season. Jim's first day in Black Hawk was not very clear, as he didn't meet many people. He encountered Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer. Jim went out of town to see an advertisement. He felt refreshed. He met an old farming family he knew. The land had been restored to a great extent. Jim sat down and looked around. He remembered the first time he came here by boat from Virginia. He felt that he and Antonia had followed similar paths to get here, and they shared a past.

He encountered Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer. Jim went out of town to see an advertisement. He felt refreshed. He met an old farming family he knew. The land had been restored to a great extent. Jim sat down and looked around. He remembered the first time he came here by boat from Virginia. He felt that he and Antonia had followed similar paths to get here, and they shared a past.

0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

They have painted their image into Macbeth's life,

Macbeth stands alone, not with them,
But do not worry, Hecate will change that.
They will meet again at midnight, when Macbeth will know his provocation,
And then a captivating song and a wind,
Everyone leaves after Hecate.

0.text: The old neighbor has problems of her own. She's a beggar and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmie's only option. She dispatches Jimmie to buy her a can of beer. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intercepts him and steals the beer. He can't cope with the 'livin hell' at home either. Jimmie hangs out before returning to the apartment. He can hear his parents fighting, threatening, and perpetrating violence on each other; the neighbors comment on how 'Ol' Johnson' is at it again. Apparently the parents have earned a bit of a reputation for hand-to-hand combat. Jimmie finally gathers the courage to return, and when he does, he finds his drunken parents passed out on the floor. He and Maggie hold each other, quivering and scared, until 'the ghost mists of dawn' arrive.

Frightened by the Queen, the Duchess finally leaves and Alice is now encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Turtle. The Queen orders the Gryphon  to take Alice to the Mock turtle. The Mock Turtle, sitting on a little rocky ledge, is sad and constantly sighing. Alice requests the Mock Turtle to tell her, his history. The Mock Turtle very proudly lists the various subjects that were taught to him. The subjects include, Reeling and Writhing and the different branches of Arithmetic . Apart from this were Mystery, Seaography, Drawling, Stretching and Fainting. What excites Alice about the Mock Turtles school is that the duration of attendance would lessen day by day. 0.text: Lydia and Wickham are found and, as expected, they are not married. Mrs. Bennet, upon hearing that Lydia is to be married, forgets the disgraceful state of affairs under which the marriage is coming to a pass. She enthusiastically proceeds to make arrangements for a wedding and to convey the glad tidings in the neighborhood.

0.text: Babbitt is elected as an official delegate to the annual convention for the State Association of Real Estate Boards. When Cecil Rountree, the chairman of the convention program-committee, asks Babbitt to write a paper espousing his views about real estate for the convention, Babbitt eagerly accepts the honor. However, he encounters trouble in writing the paper because he becomes mired in concerns about 'Style, Order, and other mysteries. ' Finally, he dispenses with all of these concerns and produces a concise, clear presentation on his thoughts about the real estate business. Babbitt reads his paper before the convention and is instantly hailed as the equal of Cecil Rountree, who is known as a 'diplomat of business.' Babbitt revels in his newfound respect and decides not to return home right away. He remains behind to drink, smoke, attend a burlesque show, and visit a brothel with some of the other delegates. Afterwards, Babbitt never tells anyone about that evening. When he returns to Zenith, it is business as usual.

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. 0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

When she reads in peace, John and his siblings look at Jane and inform their younger cousins about Jane's difficult situation in the family. As a waif-like child of Mrs. Reed, Jane is not allowed to stay with the younger children. John throws a book at Jane and calls her 'witch' and 'misery.' The children quarrel, and Jane is punished by being banished to the red room.

The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. 0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

Doctor Manette was a customer of Tellson Bank in Paris. Mr. Lorry was sent to confirm this. I hope, Lucie, that you will take care of your father and bring happiness to your brother.

Lucie was astonished by this news and her eyes filled with tears. A beautiful blonde woman appeared in the room, dusting herself into it with a chrysanthemum flower and a glass of cold water for the young woman.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

2.text:
The first chapter is noteworthy for the introduction of one of several legend's symbols. A large crowd of curious onlookers, with wide-open eyes, gathered outside the old witch's house in Boston during the seventeenth century. The house's thick, ominous black wooden door was designed to withstand dangerous criminals. For over a hundred years, it had always been home to a gallows and a scaffold. The people of Boston had constructed their own gallows decades earlier. In an extravagant announcement, an inappropriate detail in the tattered poster was the green wreath adorning the door of the witch's house. The narrator suggests that it emits a pleasant fragrance.

The people of Boston had constructed their own gallows decades earlier. The narrator leads to an enticing fragrance.

0.text: Tom Foster moved to Winesburg with his grandmother as a teenager. She cleans Banker White's house. Tom used to be the stable boy at the Whites' house, but because he is rather dreamy and irresponsible, he lost that position. Now, he does odd jobs and is quite happy. His grandmother comes regularly to clean his rented rooms, and he has a rather oddly disciplined approach to life experiences. He wants to do things, but he chooses specific experiences and then goes out and intentionally lives them. For example, having fallen in love with Helen White, he limits what he allows himself to think about her. One night, he decides he ought to try drinking to see what it feels like. He buys a bottle of whiskey and walks about a mile north of town, where he sits on a bank of grass and gets drunk. In his drunkenness, he goes and talks to George Willard about Helen. George is upset at first, but then they cement a bond between them. Tom decides that, now that he has been drunk, he will not need to try it again.

2.text:
Toán Foster came to Winesburg with my step-father when I was still very young. My step-father was the proprietor of Nhà Sáng. 0.text: In this short scene, Quince and Flute are searching for their missing friend, Bottom. They worry that 'Pyramus and Thisbe' won't be performed without him. Theseus is known for his generosity, and the actors believe they will potentially be rewarded with a lifelong pension for their stellar performance of this play. As they lament this lost opportunity, Bottom suddenly returns. His friends want to hear his story, but Bottom tells them there isn't time for that now: They must prepare for the play. He warns them to avoid onions and garlic so their breath will be sweet for the 'sweet comedy' they will perform.

He calmly tells them that they should avoid drinking mead and green oil to ensure they have a pleasant aroma for the 'pleasant problem' they will screen.

0.text: Mr. Weston is a native of Highbury. He met and married Miss Churchill over the objections of her brother, and she died three years later after bearing them a son, Frank. Weston eventually gave Frank up to his wife's brother and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, to raise, as they had more money and could support him better, and Frank eventually even took the name Churchill. Mr. Weston purchased a small estate in Highbury. He sees his son every year in London, and everyone in Highbury thinks Frank Churchill is one of their own, and all talk about him with pride even though they have never met him. Now with the marriage of Mr. Weston and Miss Taylor, everyone thinks that he will have to come and visit soon to meet the new Mrs. Weston. Instead Mrs. Weston gets a very nice letter from him that everyone in Highbury approves of and cannot talk about enough

Afterwards, Mr. Weston entrusted Frank's care to the Weston family, allowing them to provide him with a better farming household and financial resources. Frank eventually changed the name of the household. Mr. Weston purchased a small farming estate in Highbury. He returned to London once a year to visit Frank, and the people of Highbury regarded Frank as one of their own, speaking fondly of him. Now, due to Mr. Weston's engagement to Miss Taylor, the people of Highbury believe that he will come immediately to introduce Frank to his new family. However, Mrs. Weston received a beautiful letter from Frank, and the people of Highbury were surprised.

0.text: In order to best describe Typee life, the narrator profiles a typical day. Usually, they wake late, after the sun is up. Then they rise and bathe in a nearby refreshing stream. A light breakfast is enjoyed and then pipes are smoked. After breakfast, people tend to whatever they like. Tinor inspects her cloth and food supplies; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls adorn their hair and skin with oils. The narrator usually wanders with Kory-Kory or else sits inside. Then they enjoy a midday nap. Usually in the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it resembles a happy bachelor pad where the best food can be found and where the men sit around smoking and talking. After night falls, a light evening meal of 'poee-poee,' cooked breadfruit, is eaten. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then sleeps. In general, life with the Typees resembles a continual gentle slumber, with activities in between

2.text: To allow Dack-Rieng to live freely, they wrote a daily account of their lives. Normally, they slept deeply after a cold rain. Then they spread themselves out in the wind, near a river. After eating breakfast, they usually checked their mats and supplies; Marheyo worked at home. They bathed with oil and flowers and put on perfume. Normally, they followed Kory-Kory or stayed home. After the harvest festival, they usually took a siesta in the afternoon. Normally, they went to Ti, where the officials were holding court, so Ti was like the most beautiful eye in an empty space, the best food that could be found, and the people who were always talking. After a wide night.

4.text: To live freely at Phía Dack-Rieng, they wrote a day of their life. Regularly, they slept deeply after a rainstorm. Then, they spread out in the wind near a river. After eating, they usually checked their sleeping mats and belongings; Marheyo worked at home. They used oil and incense and wore a loincloth. Regularly, they followed Kory-Kory or stayed home. After a harvest festival, they usually slept soundly all day. Regularly, they went to Ti, which was where the government wrote decrees. Ti was always like a beautiful eye in the empty expanse, the best food, and a person who always spoke. After a long, open night.

6.text:
To live at Phía Dack-Rieng, they recorded the days of their eyes. They usually slept deeply after a heavy rain. Then, they played in the wind near a river. After eating, they often checked their belongings and Marheyo worked at home. They used oil lamps and air conditioners, and kept things as they were. They usually followed Kory-Kory or stayed home. After a joyful leap into emptiness, they usually slept soundly all day. They usually went to Ti, a place of law and geography. Ti was always like a beautiful eye in the vast expanse, the best food, and a person who always spoke. After a long night.

(Note: The names Marheyo and Kory-Kory, as well as some other words, are kept unchanged because they do not have a direct English definition and may not have value in the English context.)

0.text: Cinna the poet is on his way to attend Caesar's funeral when he is accosted by a group of riotous citizens who demand to know who he is and where he is going. He tells them that his name is Cinna and his destination is Caesar's funeral. They mistake him, however, for the conspirator Cinna and move to assault him. He pleads that he is Cinna the poet and not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will kill him anyway because of 'his bad verses.' With Cinna captive, the crowd exits, declaring their intent to burn the houses belonging to Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

2.text: Cinna, the scholar teacher, was on his way to Caesar's feast when he was intercepted by a group of soldiers planning to attack, asking him for his name and intending to. He replied that his name was Cinna, and he was on his way to Caesar's feast. The soldiers, mistakenly identifying him as Cinna the servant, wanted to attack. Cinna made it clear that he was Cinna the poet and not Cinna the servant, but they responded that they would kill him for 'evil rumors.' With Cinna captured, the conspirators, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius, investigated Brutus' house to persuade him.

4.text:
Cinna, scholar, was on his way to Caesar's gift when he was stopped by a group of soldiers, who asked him for the tribute and wanted to search him. He replied that his unique name was Cinna and he was on his way to Caesar's gift. The soldiers, mistakenly thinking Cinna was Cinna, the commoner, intended to attack. Cinna protested that he was Cinna, the scholar, not Cinna, the commoner, but they replied that they would arrest him anyway due to 'bad news'. With Cinna arrested, the group of conspirators, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius, went to Brutus' house to explain.

In English:

Cinna, a scholar, was on his way to Caesar's gift when he was stopped by a group of soldiers. They asked him for the tribute and wanted to search him. He replied that his name was Cinna and he was going to Caesar's gift. The soldiers, mistaking him for Cinna, the commoner, intended to attack. Cinna protested that he was Cinna, the scholar, not Cinna, the commoner, but they replied that they would arrest him anyway due to 'bad news'. With Cinna arrested, the conspirators, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius, went to Brutus' house to explain.

In Vietnamese:

Cinna, một giáo sư, đang đi đến quà Caesar khi bị phân tích bởi một nhóm binh solder. Họ hỏi ông tribute và muốn tìm kiếm. Ông trả lời rằng tên mình là Cinna và ông đang đi đến quà Caesar. Binh solder, sai lầm xem ông là Cinna, dân thông thường, muốn tấn công. Cinna đã đảng báo rằng mình là Cinna, nhà sách và không phải

6.text:
Cinnas, a Vietnamese scholar, was making amends with Caesar when he was interrupted by a group of soldiers. They asked him for a denarius each and wanted to find Caesar. Cinnas replied that his name was Cinna and he was making amends with Caesar. The soldiers, mistakenly believing him to be Cinna, a commoner, intended to attack. Cinna asserted that he was not the scholar Cinna but a commoner named Cinna. However, the soldiers replied that he would still be arrested for 'gathering information.' With Cinna arrested, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius went to Brutus' house to explain.

(Note: In this translation, 'Caesar' remains unchanged, and 'Cinna' is translated as 'Cinna, học giả' for 'Cinna, the scholar' and 'Cinna, ngường thông thường' for 'Cinna, the commoner.')

8.text: name was indeed Cinnas and that he was conversing with Caesar. However, the soldiers, under the mistaken belief that this nobleman was an ordinary Cinnas, intended to attack. Cinnas asserted that the nobleman was not the scholar Cinnas but merely an ordinary man with a similar name. Nevertheless, they replied that he would still be punished for 'processing information.' With Cinnas being taken into custody, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius went to Brutus' house to clarify the situation further.

10.text: Scholar Cinnas is Cicero and he is receiving Caesar. According to the mistaken belief of the soldiers, this Cinnas is seen as a Cinnas who intends to attack. Cinnas denies that these two people are scholar Cinnas but only one of them has that name. They replied that he would still be punished for 'processing information.' When Cinnas was arrested, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius went to Brutus' house to discuss the next strategy.

Cinna replied that they were not the same, only bearing the same name. They replied that he would still be punished for 'mismanaging information.' When captured, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius went to Brutus' house to discuss the plan in detail.

Cinna trả lời rằng họ không giống nhau, chỉ một họa với tên giống nhau. Họ trả lời rằng anh sẽ vẫn bị phạt cho 'xử lý thông tin không đúng.' Khi được bắt được, Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca và Caius Ligarius đi đến nhà Brutus để thảo luận chi tiết hơn về kế hoạch.

0.text: After one day of being on the 'Henrietta', Fogg takes over as the Captain of the ship after having bribed the entire crew and after locking Andrew Speedy in a cabin. Fogg wished to take the ship to Liverpool. Everything went well for the first few days and then the ship got caught in a gale. The ship has to fight the wind and they lose time as a result. Also since the ship had been traveling on full steam the vessel runs out of coal, as fuel. Fogg nevertheless asks the engineer to run the ship on full steam. He then summons Speedy and pays him enough money to be allowed to burn parts of the ship, in order to use them as fuel. Speedy appreciates the large sum of money and lets Fogg do whatever he wants with the ship. The ship manages to reach Queenstown Harbor and Fogg plans to go to Liverpool from here. They reach Liverpool, and now have only six hours in which to reach England. At this moment, Fix arrests Fogg.

2.text: After managing cargo on 'Henrietta' for a day, Fogg regained control by seizing all cargo and bringing Andrew Speedy into a room. Fogg intended to transport the cargo to Liverpool. The weather conditions were good for the first few days, but later, the cargo was lost at sea due to a storm. They had to fight the wind and lost valuable time. Note that the cargo was traveling faster than its full capacity, so the fuel on the cargo had run out. Fogg then demanded a representative to increase the cargo's full capacity. Later, Fogg called Speedy back and registered enough money to allow him to use a part of the cargo as fuel. Speedy loved large sums of money and allowed Fogg to do as he pleased with the cargo. The cargo could reach Tan Thet Harbor, and Fogg wanted to travel from there to Liverpool. They arrived in Liverpool, as

4.text: Fogg managed the cargo on 'Henrietta' for a day, took back control by seizing all the cargo and summoned Andrew Speedy into the room. Fogg intended to transport the cargo to Liverpool. The weather conditions were favorable for a few days, but afterwards, the cargo disappeared due to a storm. Despite the good weather, they had to fight against the wind and lost precious time. It should be noted that the cargo was moving faster than its full capacity, hence the fuel on the cargo had run out. Later, Fogg requested an increase in the total cargo capacity. Then, Fogg called Speedy back and registered enough funds to allow him to use a part of the cargo as fuel. Speedy was fond of large sums of money and agreed, allowing Fogg to continue with the cargo. The cargo could reach Tan Thet Harbor, and Fogg wanted to go from there to Liverpool. They arrived in Liverpool.

6.text: Fogg, the cargo manager of 'Henrietta,' took charge of cargo management for a day, and called Andrew Speedy into his office. Fogg wanted to transport cargo to Liverpool. The weather conditions were favorable for a few days, but then the cargo disappeared due to heavy rain. Under good weather conditions, they had to fight against the wind and lost precious time. It's important to note that the cargo was moving faster than its maximum weight, so the fuel on the cargo had run out. Later, Fogg requested an increase in the total weight of the cargo. After that, Fogg called Speedy again and provided enough surplus to allow him to use a portion of the cargo as fuel. Speedy was very fond of large sums of money and agreed, helping Fogg continue with the cargo. The cargo could reach Tan Thet Harbor, and Fogg wanted to go from there to Liverpool. They went to Liverpool.

8.text: Phím, managing goods for 'Henrietta', manages the cargo daily, then calls Andrew Nhanh to his office. Phím wants to transport goods to Liverpool. The weather conditions are good for a few days, but then the goods were lost due to heavy rain. When the weather conditions are good, they have to fight directly with the wind and lose precious time. Note that the cargo moves faster than the maximum weight limit, so the fuel in the cargo has run out. Then, Phím requested an increase in the weight of the cargo. After that, Phím called Nhanh again and provided enough evaluation for them to use a part of the cargo as fuel. Nhanh agreed to the large sum of money and allowed Phím to continue with the cargo transport. The cargo can reach Tan Thet Harbor, and Phím wants to go from there to Liverpool. They went to Liverpool.

10.text: The 'Henrietta' warehouse management system notifies 'Phím' about daily shipments, then calls Andrew Nhanh's office to schedule transport to Liverpool with suitable weather conditions. However, the cargo was lost due to heavy rain during those days. When conditions are favorable, they have to compete directly with the wind and lose valuable time. However, expedited cargo shipping caused them to run out of fuel for transportation. Phím requested an increase in cargo weight. Phím called back Nhanh and provided an evaluation sufficient for them to use part of the cargo as fuel. Nhanh agreed with a large sum of money and allowed Phím to continue shipping the cargo. The cargo could reach Tan Thet Port, and Phím intended to go from there to Liverpool. They went to Liverpool.

13.text:
The 'Henrietta' warehouse management system informs 'Phím' about daily shipments and calls Andrew Nhanh's office to schedule transportation to Liverpool under favorable weather conditions. However, the cargo was lost due to heavy rain during that period. When the conditions are good, they have to compete directly with the wind and lose valuable time. However, expedited cargo shipping caused them to run out of fuel for transportation. Phím requested an increase in cargo weight. Phím contacted Nhanh again and presented an evaluation that allowed them to use part of the cargo as fuel. Nhanh agreed with a large sum of money and permitted Phím to continue shipping the cargo. The cargo arrived at Tan Thet Port, and Phím intended to go from there to Liverpool. They went to Liverpool.

Tuy nhiên, hàng hóa bị mất bởi mưa lớn trong thời gian đó. Khi điều kiện tốt, họ phải thi đấu trực tiếp với gió và mất thời gian quý giá. Tuy nhiên, vận chuyển hàng hóa nhanh gây ra sự hết nhiên liệu cho phương tiện vận chuyển. Phím yêu cầu tăng trọng lượng hàng hóa. 0.text: Sir Claude explains to Maisie that he doesn't love her mother, adding that Mrs. Beale doesn't love her father, either. This prompts Maisie to ask whether he's been seeing Mrs. Beale after all. Sir Claude says no, but he's written to her. But, here again, James is hinting at greater intimacy between Maisie's two stepparents. You guessed it: foreshadowing. Shortly after this conversation with Sir Claude, Maisie hears from Mrs. Wix that he has been secretly seeing Mrs. Beale. Mrs. Wix is convinced of this. Maisie has a hard time accepting that Sir Claude would have lied to her. But soon enough, she gets proof that he has been seeing Mrs. Beale when he takes her to her father's house to see her. Before they arrive at Mrs. Beale's, Sir Claude says that he doesn't think Mrs. Wix's plan for all of them to live together will work out. But, he says Maisie can stay with Mrs. Beale, and he will come to visit her often. Maisie accepts. Maisie realizes that this means she won't get to see Mrs. Wix or say goodbye--but only after it's too late.

He was faithful to a woman for whom his loss is particularly devastating. Ooh, a clue. Now that he's gone, everyone realizes how great he was. Even though his position on the throne made him especially vulnerable to criticism, he appears blameless. Who could wish for a better life for his only son, or hope for more for his son's sons than that they resemble such an excellent father--Albert the Good? 0.text: The Islet David finds himself on a small islet, cut off from the mainland by a small river. He tries to cross the river, but finds it is too wide and deep. He returns to the shore to get his piece of wood, planning to try and float across, but the yard has floated back out to sea. David is now miserable. He begins eating raw shellfish. Sometimes he manages to keep them down, and other times they make him extremely sick. He is especially depressed because he can see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knows he cannot cross the river. The next day he sees, to his surprise, a red deer, which he realizes must have swum the river. He also discovers that he has lost all his money after the shipwreck. He sees some fisherman, and wildly hails them from the shore. But, to his shock, they only point and laugh at him. The fishermen return later and, in broken English, reveal to him that the river gets very low at low tide. To his surprise and embarrassment, he finds he can practically hop across the river at low tide

2.text:
David discovered he was on a small island, distinguished by a small river. He tried to cross it but found it to be wide and deep. He returned to the shore to collect firewood, intending to check if it could be used for a raft, but the forest returned to its original position. David was sad. He started eating wild fruits. Usually they brought him joy, but once they caused him a big problem. He was surprised to see a vine of flowers and houses on the island, but he knew he couldn't cross the river.

The next day, he saw a red deer, named Cho Dat, crossing the river. He also realized he had run out of money after the boat accident. He called out to a group of people he saw, but they only stared at him with their eyes and turned their backs. They returned later and, using sign language, offered to help him cross the river.

0.text: The wanderer. While walking across London, David encounters Mr. Peggotty, who has been to continental Europe in search of Little Em'ly. While Mr. Peggotty is talking to David at an inn, David notices Martha listening just outside the door. Mr. Peggotty heard reports of sightings of Little Em'ly in Switzerland with Steerforth and Littimer, but did not find her. He shows David letters he has received from Little Em'ly, one expressing guilt at the suffering she has caused Mr. Peggotty and Ham, and two containing money. Mr. Peggotty reports that Ham has lost care for his own life and is putting himself forward for many dangerous tasks at sea. Mr. Peggotty goes to an inn where he will spend the night before resuming his search

2.text:
In Vietnamese: Đại Bính. Khi đi qua London, David gặp ông Peggoty. Ông Peggoty đi tới Châu Âu để tìm Emmy Bones. Khi ông Peggoty nói chuyện với David tại một chùa, David nghe thấy tên Martha được gọi ngoài cửa. Ông Peggoty nhận được thông tin rằng Emmy Bones được thấy tại Switzerland với Steerforth và Littler, nhưng chưa xác minh. Ông Peggoty đã đưa cho David các thư gửi từ Emmy Bones, một thư giải quyết cho vi phạm gây đau cho Mr. Peggoty và Ham, và hai thư gồm tiền. Ông Peggoty đã nói đến David rằng Ham đã mất sự quan tâm đến cuộc sống mình và đang tình trọng nhiều hoạt động bảo vệ tàu tại bờ biển. Ông Peggoty đi đến một chùa để mời thánh trong đêm trước khi tiếp tục tìm kiếm.

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph are near Coventry, in the midlands. Falstaff sends Bardolph along ahead of him. Alone, Falstaff confides that in the conscription of soldiers, he has been cheating. He has allowed men of means to buy themselves out of military service, providing him with a profit. The soldiers that remain are a pathetic, ragged bunch, not fit for battle, or for anything. Falstaff has recruited some of them direct from prison. Prince Hal and Westmoreland enter. They both comment on how pitiful Falstaff's men appear. Falstaff replies that his men will fill a grave as well as any other. As the Prince departs, he tells Falstaff to make haste to Shrewsbury.

They spoke of Falstaff's men being unfit. Falstaff replied that they would dig deep as any man could. When Prince Hal left, Falstaff called for a phone to come to Shrewsbury quickly.

0.text: Cyrano commends Christian's bravery and, to Christian's astonishment, embraces him. Cyrano tells Christian that he is Roxane's cousin and that she loves him. Christian apologizes to Cyrano for insulting him. Christian fears that Roxane will lose interest in him as soon as he speaks to her, as he is so stupid. Cyrano proposes that he join his eloquence to Christian's good looks to create the perfect lover for Roxane. He will write some eloquent speeches for Christian to deliver to Roxane as his own. Cyrano claims that he only wants to do this to practise his literary skills. From his pocket, he produces the letter he wrote earlier to Roxane and hands it to Christian to give to her. Christian embraces Cyrano in gratitude. The other Guards, Lise, and the Musketeer enter and are astonished to see Cyrano embracing Christian. The Musketeer believes that Cyrano must have undergone a transformation that means it is safe to talk about his nose. He impudently stares at Cyrano's nose, asking what the smell could be. 0.text: Banquo and his son Fleance walk toward their rooms after all of the merrymaking is over. Banquo tells Fleance that he is unable to sleep because of his troubling thoughts. He is wondering if Macbeth will take fate into his own hands to try and realize the witches' prophecies. The pair meets up with Macbeth, who is also roaming the hallways. Banquo tells Macbeth of King Duncan's pleasure at having been so royally treated. He asks Macbeth if he has been thinking of the weird sisters; Macbeth falsely responds in the negative. Again, he asks Banquo to talk with him at a later date about the strange events of that night. It seems that Macbeth seeks an intelligent and compassionate friend like Banquo to be his confidante in crime. Macbeth summons his wife and suddenly finds himself clutching a dagger, which stuns him. He sees imaginary drops of blood on the dagger that he will use to kill Duncan. Lady Macbeth gives him the signal, and he proceeds towards Duncan's room to kill him
